story: The Met Office forecast for today shows most areas becoming cloudy as the day rolls on.Some patchy rain will move across Northern Ireland and Scotland, but the heaviest outbreaks should be behind you.Tonight, we&rsquoll see occasional rain for Northern Ireland, southern Scotland and parts of northwest England.And as the week progresses, things will turn more unsettled, with showers and strong winds likely, particularly in the north and west.                UK weather forecast: SHOCK chart shows rain and 'strong winds' hit UK                BBC weather forecast mapped: &lsquoStrong&rsquo rain showers to hit north west                UK weather forecast: PLUMMETING temperatures to disrupt heatwaveMet Office weather forecast: This map shows today's temperatures (Image: WINDY)A spokesman added: &ldquoHowever, we will probably see some longer dry and settled spells at times, these perhaps becoming more dominant in the north and northwest.&ldquoTemperatures are likely to be generally warmer than average, but as we go into September there will an increasing chance of some chillier nights.This latest forecast comes on the back of an unusually dramatic UK summer, with incredibly hot spells punctuated by massive thunderstorms.On July 26, Faversham in Kent saw temperatures reach 35.3C, the highest July temperature since July 1, 2015, when Heathrow saw a peak of 36.7C.Met Office weather forecast: Tthere is a chance of an Indian summer still to come. (Image: Getty )The hottest temperature ever recorded in the UK was 38.5C, at Faversham on August 10, 2003.According to the Met Office, July was the hottest July in southern regions since records began, with an average daily temperature of 26.2C.The heatwave was caused by the jet stream - a current of air that usually pushes high pressure away from the UK - migrating further north, allowing the pressure to build.On June 27, a major incident was declared in Greater Manchester when a wildfire raged out of control, showing the darker side of the summer sun.The heatwave has also put pressure on the NHS and health providers as they battle to cope with the demands of heatwave-related ailments.

title: EU news European Union Parliament election 2019 populist revolt
story: A populist takeover in Parliament would enable anti-EU politicians to dictate the bloc's powerful executive body, the European Commission, killing off the EU as we know it.Anti-EU movements are gearing up in their preparations for May 2019&rsquos European parliamentary elections, which will decide the future make-up of the Brussels leadership.High-profile right-wing figures Matteo Salvini and Steve Bannon have both signalled, separately, their intention to disrupt the establishment with populist movements.Guntram Wolff, director of the Bruegel think tank in Brussels, said: &ldquoThere will be a lot of things happening in terms of the more anti-European parties and I think they will have quite a strong percentage overall.&ldquoThe question is: will these get organised and unify in one party group?                EU WARNED: Italy deputy PM Salvini issues STERN warning to Brussels &ldquoIf so, they could become the largest or the second-largest group in the Parliament.Alberto Alemanno, a professor of EU law in Paris, said: Europe may be on the verge of a more trans-national form of democracy &ndash one that is polarised around very basic pro and anti-EU positions.Under current spitzenkandidat rules, the process used to select the Commission president, the largest political group in the parliament selects the candidate who becomes the EU's most senior official.The current incumbent, Jean-Claude Juncker, is expected to stand down and a new Commission president appointed after the May 2019 elections.While Mr Juncker's EPP are once again likely to become the largest group in Parliament, a significant increase in populist MEPs will cause his predecessor a headache.Because of the law-making process in Brussels, Parliament has the power to veto any legislatory proposals put forward by the Commission.MEPs even have the opportunity to reject any amendments tabled by member states, which thus far have been reasonably sucessful in keeping populists at bay.During the Parliament's current term, eurosceptic forces have been kept at defeated in Germany and France.However, Brussels has been a hotbed for anti-establishment success with 151 of the current 751 MEPs identifying as eurosceptic.If the number of populist can grow in the next make-up of Parliament, they will carry significant power in the decision-making process and if teamed up could even take control of the Commission.&nbsp&nbspMatteo Salvini is just one right-winger who can rock EU politics at next year's election (Image: )In July, Mr Salvini, Italy&rsquos deputy prime minister and leader of right-wingers League, pledged to &ldquoliberate Europeans in the same way he has with Italians, spearheading an anti-establishment coalition with the Five Star Movement.Addressing an outdoor rally in northern Italy, the populist heavyweight proclaimed his and League&rsquos idealism is the &ldquolast hope for this Europe to stay alive, promising to produce a similar movement in the heart of Brussels politics.Mr Salvini told the Pontida crowd: &ldquoI am thinking about a League of the Leagues of Europe, bringing together all the free and sovereign movements that want to defend their people and their borders.He said League would be at the front of Italian politics for the next 30 years and he will unleash his mantra of European politics at the next vote to elect MEPs in May 2019.                EU ready to BUCKLE to Italy as it backs down on austerity                Brexit news: EU PANICS no-deal will hit bloc HARDER than UKMr Bannon, former White house strategist for Donald Trump, is planning on setting up a Brussels-based foundation, The Movement, to help right-wing parties coordinate their efforts in the upcoming vote.He said: Everybody agrees that next May is hugely important, that this is the real first continent-wide face-off between populism and the party of Davos.This will be an enormously important moment for Europe.In previous votes, the emphasis has been on the Continental debt-crisis and solving the illegal migration from Africa and the Middle East.Steve Bannon is hoping to inspire a conservative revolt with his own Brussels-based office (Image: )But now, eurosceptic politicians have the opportunity to put the issue of national sovereignty championed by Brexit on their campaign platform.There are even fears that a prolonged Brexit process would create the perfect platform for populists to campaign on.An insider told Express EU chiefs would not risk granting an extension to Article 50 because it would also grant every populist MEP the right to accuse Brussels of acting like a dictatorship.&ldquoAn extension would be a boom to populists right across Europe, &lsquoeven if you vote to leave they won't let you&rsquo, they said.

In 2016, Northern Ireland exported around &pound4 billion worth of goods and services to the south.The Republic exported roughly &pound1.3 billion of goods in the same year, according to their own figures.Brexit news: Germany and France amongst countries who could be hit by no-deal orce (Image: )FranceParis&rsquo &pound4 billion trade surplus with Britain would be put at significant risk if no withdrawal deal is reached.Gerald Darmanian, a French finance minister, said a no-deal Brexit would a &ldquodisaster for the flow of goods between Britain and the Continent.France is also fuming after European Commission planning decided to exclude French ports from new shipping routes between Ireland and the Continent.This means Paris&rsquo coastal ports could lose on on billions of EU funding to help increase their capacity after Brexit.                &lsquoI GUARANTEE it!&rsquo City expert bets &pound3.6BN on UK negotiating free trade                'UNACCEPTABLE' French FURY over EU plan to EXCLUDE French ports GermanyBerlin currently enjoys trade deals with Britain that are worth &pound61 billion, which the Federation of German Industry warns are at risk in the event of a no deal.The BDI is worried about increased friction in trade with Britain after Brexit. The UK is the second-biggest export market for German car manufacturers.Customs duties of &pound2 billion a year would be added to the cost of German cars bought by British consumers under a no-deal Brexit.Last year, 950,000 cars made by Volkswagen, BMW and Mercedes-Benz were registered in the UK as part of the &pound20 billion worth of German cars that were imported.Dominic Raab and Michel Barnier are working to strike a deal but EU members fear the worst (Image: )BelgiumA no-deal Brexit will hurt the Belgian economy seriously, according to shock warnings from its finance minister Johan Van Overtveldt.The country will lose around 42,000 in the Flanders region alone as havoc is wreaked across the small nation.Mr Van Overtveldt said: Belgium is the fourth exporter, in nominal amounts, into the UK, on a par with France which is a much bigger country. And so, if Brexit goes the wrong way, in terms of the hard Brexit, it will hurt the Belgian economy seriously.We&rsquore talking about thousands and thousands of jobs depending on the business done with the UK.ItalyRome could have to contribute an extra &pound900 million a year into Brussels' budget coffers in order to make up the shortfall left by Brexit.The country's farmers are also concerned that any restriction in free trade between the Italy and the UK would devastate their industry.Roberto Moncalvo, president of Italian farming union Coldiretti said the UK&rsquos exit from the EU in March 2019 would &ldquoweaken Italy&rsquos farming industry and export trade.He warned Italian agriculture &ldquocan&rsquot pay the price of Brexit.They fear an estimated cut of &euro2.7billion (&pound2.3billion) to the budget of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), something which could heavily impact 800,000 Italian farms.

title: a level grade boundaries ucas results day 2018
story: But the last thing you want to be stressing about is when you will receive your results - so heres what you need to know.Grade boundaries will be published from 8am on Thursday, August 16, 2018, and are available on each exam boards website.This is the same day as A-level results day, when pupils can go to their school or college to receive their marks.These boundaries show the minimum number of marks that students need for each grade.The grade boundaries are normally released online the day before candidates receive their GCSE and A-level results, but it has been changed to be published on the same day.TES reported that the decision to delay the publication of the grade boundaries was to prevent students from becoming overly anxious about their results and panicking that they would not achieve the necessary grade.It comes after the governments pledge in 2017 to toughen up the end of year exams was left in tatters - with the marks needed for top grades lowered to prevent a massive fall in results this summer.Each exam board has its own grade boundary.Ucas is a service that allows students to follow their university application online.The Track became available from 8am on Thursday, August 1, 2018, updating records for each applicant.Students do not see their A-level results through the service, instead they receive them from their school or college.Despite the myth, Track does not update at midnight before the release of the results.More than 40 advisers will be on hand for the expected influx of thousands of learners who receive unexpected results and need support and guidance on what to do next.If you’ve received your exam results (A-levels, GCSEs, Scottish Highers and Standards) and need advice on what to do next, call the Exam Results Helpline for free, independent advice on 0800 100 900.Students are able to use clearing to find out what courses still have places remaining.If students have not been successful with their first preference, they are able to search for a course against the subject they are interested in, or the university they want to head to.All results will be sent to schools or colleges electronically on Wednesday, August 22.The date students will be able to receive their grades is on Thursday, August 23.This year will be the second time the numbers-based grading system will be used, with English and maths students getting a score from 1-9 rather than U-A*.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady column self harm
story: New research reveals that the number of girls aged 13 to 16 reporting self-harm to GPs has increased by 68 per cent over just three years.It’s a staggering rise — and that is just the reported cases.Given that self-harm tends to be a solitary pursuit, I think it’s realistic to assume that there are many, many more unreported cases.Self-harm among young people aged ten to 19 is three times more common among girls than boys. Bearing in mind that those who self-harm are at much greater risk of suicide, this is not a problem to be taken lightly.For some young people the act of cutting, or otherwise inflicting pain on themselves, is a way of relieving — albeit temporarily — mental pain and torment by converting it into something more visible and tangible.It’s a way of relieving tension and an attempt to clarify a confusing mental swirl into something that is easier to understand in its simplicity. It’s also a way of punishing yourself.So why the sudden, huge, increase in girls taking this path?Psychiatrists commenting on the research blamed a combination of academic stresses and body-image issues triggered by the use of social media.There’s no doubt that social media, which barely existed ten years ago, has, along with all the good stuff, brought with it a whole new set of pressures.Women’s appearances have always been scrutinised, but that unique equation of the selfie generation plus Photoshop plus the sheer variety of ways to propel your image out into the world has created a series of impossible standards.It’s also created a whole generation that is convinced that everything is going brilliantly for everyone else.When teenagers look at their friend’s social media feeds they see apparently perfect lives, bodies, homes and jobs.And then they feel inadequate.There are other pressures: Pressure to do well in exams have amazing friendships and be brilliantly successful. And, for some people, the relief to those pressures is to hurt themselves, which is surely the saddest and one of the most difficult problems any parent can deal with.After all, it’s our natural instinct to protect our children from harm. But what can we do when the harm comes from within themselves?All teenage kids have intensely difficult phases. And the pressures at school can feel unbearable.If someone doesn’t like you, it feels like the end of the world. If you fail an exam you can feel doomed to failure. School feels like it will never end.Our job is to try to help our children get perspective.Despite the downsides of excessive social media being well documented, it seems that most young people would rather end up with mental health problems than give it up. So maybe they need a helping hand.We need to talk more to our kids about the reality of social media — and limit their time on it.And we need to coax them out of their screen-sized comfort zone.One of the best things kids can do is some volunteering.That way they can meet kids from different backgrounds and people with real problems — such as children born with disabilities who are still making the most of their life.Sport is also brilliant for getting kids to enjoy being part of something bigger than their bedroom, and for celebrating their bodies for what they can do rather than what they look like.The big question is, how can we get them to talk about their feelings, instead of engraving them into their skin until they draw blood?Be kind, patient but determined and, most importantly, we need to talk to our children, ask them how they are feeling — and listen to the answers without judgment.If they won’t talk to you, find someone else they can talk to, either a family friend or even a counsellor if you’re worried about self-harm.But the Government also needs to invest more money into care.Less than one per cent of the NHS budget is spent on children’s mental health, and most of that is on acute care rather than preventative or early intervention services.That needs to change.Most of all, we need to accept that there is a problem and find ways to address it. Because if we don’t, things are going to get much, much worse.SURELY only those with the hardest of hearts could complain about the affection shown by Zara and Mike Tindall, who are frequently photographed kissing, hugging and looking generally happy and totally loved-up.Given they have survived challenging personal losses and have two young children, it’s pretty much a miracle they are so happy.How could anyone wish them anything but well?DID you see the Kardashian and Jenner sisters at Kylie Jenner’s 21st birthday party?What is most striking – other than them all being drop-dead gorgeous, of course – is that they each have totally different body types.I guess what they DO have in common is an unlimited budget for personal trainers and chefs . . . plus the fact that looking this good is their full-time job.His crime was horrific and he deserved to be dealt with.His punishment was to be beheaded and his body crucified and displayed in Mecca.A beheading and crucifixion in this century?There are instances when I do believe that the death penalty is just, but this method is just barbaric.THE latest advice from fertility specialists to women who want to “delay motherhood” is for them to freeze their eggs in their early twenties.At the moment, the vast majority of women who go through the procedure do so in their late thirties – by which time they have little chance of success. But who is going to freeze their eggs in their twenties?I was fortunate to meet the right man in my twenties – and had children once I was married because I wanted to have a family.But plenty of women don’t meet the right partner that early in life, or simply don’t want to have children until they are older.One reason for that is that they want to have a career – and they know babies can seriously damage their chances of promotion or even a pay rise.But the solution is not for women to freeze their eggs.The real solution is a shift in the division of labour between mothers and fathers.So long as the children are not the sole responsibility of just one person in the family, things can work well.If both partners are equally involved, nobody has to totally compromise their life and put their career on hold.As things stand, no wonder women are putting off motherhood. But if more men pulled their weight, maybe women wouldn’t have to worry about freezing their eggs.WHEN you look at photos of the 200 travellers who have descended on the village of Long Ditton in Surrey, you can see why local police sparked fury by telling residents who want to evict them to have empathy instead.The police force tweeted: “Consider for a second how upsetting it would be, being uprooted every few days.”But the photos show piles of rubbish and damaged property.In one, a child is sitting on an adult’s lap while he drives a car around the village green. And I dread to think about the specifics of the toilet situation.What is needed is not empathy but police action.SOME high-profile, wealthy parents – such as Sting, Elton John and Simon Cowell – make a point of saying they won’t leave their fortunes to their children for fear it will ruin their lives.Location, Location, Location presenter Kirstie Allsopp has taken a different tack.She says she will leave her £16million fortune to her two sons . . . IF they get a job.I applaud the sentiment. But if you really want your children to develop a work ethic, rather than relying on inherited income, isn’t the key not to tell your kids – and the whole world – in a national newspaper?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government hiking fuel duty
story: Britain’s motorists already get a raw deal at the petrol pump, with fuel duty among the highest in the world.Why should they be hammered further to help bankroll the £20billion NHS splurge?A hike will make people poorer, take cash out of the economy and stoke inflation. Low-paid workers, who need their cars and vans for work, will be unfairly hit.So will ordinary, hard-pressed families, who already have to budget to fill up so they can take their kids to school and transport their weekly supermarket shop.In other words, it will unfairly impact the “Just About Managings” who Theresa May once claimed she would strive to protect.Philip Hammond might regard drivers as a convenient cash cow to fill the Treasury’s coffers.But he should resist clobbering them for a quick cash injection. Targeting those struggling is political cowardice.Voters won’t forgive him.ORDINARY Brits back Boris Johnson.His joke about Muslim women wearing the full black robe looking like “letterboxes” and “bank robbers” has been portrayed as an affront.But away from all the Twitter outrage, the former Foreign Secretary is in step with public opinion.Meanwhile, Jeremy Corbyn continues to shame Labour with his anti-Semitism.Of course, just as we are free to debate the burka, people are free to debate the Israel-Palestine conflict.But a politician with aspirations to run the country should not be laying wreaths for terror leaders.Corbyn believes Israel is the ultimate malevolent force, a racist imperial outpost, causing the world’s ills at the behest of America and Britain. How many traditional Labour voters today share his worldview?It is Boris, derided by his enemies as an Etonian toff, who has his finger on the nation’s pulse and understands the concerns of ordinary people.No surprise that in one poll the Tories have opened a four-point lead over Corbyn’s Labour.After a short summer break following our fantastic World Cup, it is great to have the beautiful game back.We’ve already witnessed breathtaking goals, crunching tackles and some blinding saves.And there is nowhere better to get the best football coverage than inside Britain’s favourite newspaper.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tory new brexit plan next month
story: Arch-Brexiteers want to deliver a vision for an “alternative to Chequers” just days before a critical Tory party conference.Eurosceptics are incensed by the PM’s Chequers proposal - claiming a bid to stay in a single market for goods will tie the UK to EU rules for years to come.The plans are believed to have the support of Jacob Rees-Mogg, head of the Tory MPs ‘European Research Group’.Ex-Cabinet Minister Peter Lilley and John Redwood are looking at tariffs and trade options. It will put intense pressure on No.10 in the run-up to a party conference that could decide her fate.One source told The Sun: “This is about delivering the clean Brexit that people voted for. No concessions.”The revelation came as Tory party bigwigs sparked backlash by urging local associations to back the PM’s Chequers plan on the doorstep.Conservative HQ was branded “moronic” by Eurosceptic MPs after asking regional branches to spend a small fortune on leaflets backing the PM’s soft Brexit plan.Maria Caulfield, who quit as vice-chair of the Tory Party over Chequers, said local officers and councillors were furious. Posting on a Tory Whatsapp group she stormed: “Are the power that be determined to add insult to injury after the white paper, Boris, the PM letter and now this.”Marcus Fysh, a Eurosceptic who has called for the PM to go, added: “Uttterly moronic I’m afraid. The sooner this administration is changed the better.”They also hit out over the “Lib Dem Yellow” colour of the mailout – which explains how the Chequers proposal will end free movement, and the rule of the European Court of Justice.Brexit backers argue the PM’s plan to keep Britain in a single market for goods will force the UK to be subject to ECJ rulings for years. Separately yesterday, sources in Brussels conceded the EU could suffer more than the UK in the immediate aftermath of a No Deal Brexit.They claimed officials drawing together desperate contingency plans to keep trade links open and aircraft flying are worried whether EU institutions and EU member states will be able to act swiftly enough.BRUSSELS has admitted a No Deal could harm the EU, insiders claim.Officials are concerned whether EU institutions would be able to act quickly enough in the immediate aftermath.One said the key worry was keeping trade links open and aircraft in the skies.Eurosceptics claimed it was the start of a “climbdown”.But Whitehall insiders said it was designed to worry the UK about the risks of a hard Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun reader letters boris burka
story: But there has been a groundswell of support for BoJo from ordinary people, fed up at what they see as attacks on freedom of expression and the British way of life.This is what Sun readers have to say about the issue, and Brexit-backer Boris:BORIS Johnson has a dig at burka-wearing Muslims and our elite shake with fear. Don’t they know many thousands of people agree with him? Or do they chose to again ignore the people of this country? Any movement on Boris from the out-of-touch Government will cost them dear.SO Dominic Grieve has threatened to quit Parliament if Boris Johnson became PM. I can think of no better reason for wishing him success.BANG on Boris, about the burka. It being worn in public is scary for children who see it.FREEDOM of speech must not be compromised – and there can be no question of legal action being taken against Boris Johnson, it would be prejudiced by all the attacks on him.THIS week it has been especially hard to be a Muslim woman. Apparently I am not getting the joke, I’m over sensitive, bullied, oppressed, unintegrated, politically motivated, dividing Britain – this list goes on. Perhaps Boris Johnson’s Etonian education did not enable him to understand that in polite society it’s rude to comment with ridicule on the way people dress.ONE thing critics of Boris Johnson’s burka comment overlook is the impact of burka-wearers on those who are deaf and rely on seeing facial expressions, and lip-reading.THE do-gooders complaining about Boris are fanning the flames of hatred by highlighting issues that one wouldn’t really think about. Talk about “integration” appears to be one-sided and discriminatory towards the indigenous people. There is some equilibrium lacking in our “fair, just and equal” land of ours.WHILE I am not sure Boris used a good choice of words likening women in burkas to pillar boxes, he was right that we are frightened by what it represents. We must not destroy Boris, he is good for the people of this country, he cares. He must also be allowed to speak honestly, he has nothing to apologise for.LIGHTEN up, Boris spoke the thoughts of many millions of Brits. If making a gaffe was against the law, Prince Philip could have been banged up in the Tower of London on many occasions during the last 50 years. He wrote the book on it.Boris might have an agenda – what politician doesn’t? – but this mustn’t mean people don’t have a right to voice criticism. Face veils in public, and burkas, are not religious requirements and we must have the right to criticise the wearers.IF I was Boris Johnson, I would agree to attend the diversity training some have suggested . . . and then tear the training session to pieces.I SAW Ranvir Singh berating her guests on morning TV for daring to agree with Boris Johnson? I wonder what her bosses would say if she suggested that she presented her programme wearing a burka. I think we all know the answer to that.PHIL GROWDENNOTHING Theresa May says can be taken at face value. Not so long ago, she promised to stop the witch-hunt of British soldiers, who have seen action and survived in many parts of the world. However, the victimisation of our veterans continues unabated. They are now joined by Boris Johnson, who has frequently ignited the Prime Minister’s wrath and must therefore, be thrown to the wolves.A BUS company has apologised after a driver told a woman to remove her niqab. So would a bank apologise if a security guard asked a man to remove his ski mask?HOW would I stand as a Christian male finding a Muslim lady, dressed in a burka, having a heart attack? Would I be allowed to remove her veil to perform mouth-to-mouth?THE controversy surrounding Boris Johnson’s burka comments has reached ridiculous heights. Police conducting an investigation. Really?IF Theresa May had the guts to ban the burka like a lot of other countries, we might not be having this discussion about what Boris Johnson said.SOMETHING featureless with a rectangular hole in it can resemble a letter box, there’s probably one on your front door, go and have a look. It has also been known for the person inside to be a terrorist, not an innocent woman. Stop being so pathetic, have a sense of humour, act like adultsI READ about a motorcyclist at a filling station having to remove his crash helmet while a woman (who could have been a criminal’s getaway driver) filling up at the pump next to him was wearing a burka. Meanwhile Boris’s remarks are causing hysteria.I HAVE been visiting garden centres and supermarket car parks in my car, which is bedecked with Brexit stickers, asking many people their opinion on the Boris situation. For Boris, I find there is a great deal of love out there. For the Chequers “deal” there is none.IT’S true that Boris Johnson has used strong language but Muslim terrorists are doing far worse things than robbing banks, by committing terrorist atrocities. It would be a sad day when the Muslim community can’t take such a comment, especially when many Muslim women, in my view, do not want this clothing themselves.IT’S confirmed, lunatics are ruining the country. We have the enemy (EU) knocking art the door and all the idiots can find to discuss is Boris Johnson’s perfectly fair comment. If it wasn’t so serious it would be funny. Brexit should be top of the agenda.THERE are easily as many people who agree with BoJo’s comments as those who don’t. So why is it those who don’t will instigate an investigation, leaving those who do without a voice? Even senior Muslims and imams have said that the burka is not a requirement in Islam, so why is it we only tend to listen to those who are offended?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the last leg ally ross
story: You expect this reaction, obviously, from news organisations who have to fill endless blank hours with something during silly season.The really depressing thing, though, was that a late-night Channel 4 “comedy” show and its presenters were the most outraged of them all.I’m talking, of course, about The Last Leg which, for reasons that still escape me, genuinely fancies itself as one of television’s edgiest and funniest shows.It’s not, clearly. The Last Leg is a television safe space, the authentic voice of the PC establishment and as predictable as the sun rising in the morning.So you knew, long before Friday’s transmission, that they’d be targeting Boris, who is a thousand times funnier and edgier than anyone on this show, in his own way.Nearly a whole working week host Adam Hills and his two mates had to prepare some decent material as well, and this was the best three professional comedians could do.Alex Brooker: “The burka is an item of clothing worn by a human being, the other is a postbox, you f***ing idiot.”Adam Hills: “I’d much rather sit next to a person in burka than a p***k in a suit.”Josh Widdicombe: “Theresa May has only just realised Boris is a t**t, so she should apologise as well.”On and on it went, for 12 minutes and 54 seconds, a figure I mention because I’ve had the clock on this lot, and if you want to know exactly how much of a toss they really give about religious sensitivities then it’s best measured by the fact this series of The Last Leg has devoted just 65 hand-wringing seconds to the anti-Semitic poison infecting the Labour Party.It was crammed hurriedly into the previous episode, which was worth watching just to see Adam Hills describe Corbyn’s handling of this crisis as “a faux pas”, (which isn’t French for “shameful cluster-f***”) and the C4 audience react with evident discomfort because he’d drawn attention to the Labour leader’s failings and, therefore, broken one of comedy’s secret and golden rules.If you doubted these rules exist, incidentally, then ever the virtue-signalling fool, Adam Hills was good enough to spell them out for us on Friday.“Every religion should be open to ridicule . . . but you kind of need to be in the club.“Alex and I can make jokes about disabilities as we’re technically disabled.”Boris, he then explained, can’t make jokes about burkas, ’cos he’s “a white Etonian”, nor could comedy giant Rowan Atkinson defend him, as he was “a white man who lives in Oxford and drives an F1 car”.Even if we ignore the fact he’s assumed that all Muslims are black, something pretty staggering is going on here.For Mary Whitehouse, in all her pearl-clutching glory, never imagined anything quite as Draconian and controlling as this form of satirical Apartheid.Adam Hills has a point, though, when he uses the word “club”. That’s exactly what television comedy has become.A closed, left-wing shop where you don’t even bother joining the audience unless you follow the rigid “Tories and Brexit are evil” party line.This is not creating comedy, it’s policing it, and also the reason why applause has replaced laughter on all those Channel 4 and BBC news satires which have failed to realise there is only one simple rule to be observed when creating these shows: Make it funny, dumbo.I would suggest, at this point, Adam Hills gets off his moral high horse, for once, and gives this “funny” idea a go.But then I could also ask Boris to have a crack at anchoring the British women’s 4x100m relay team to gold at the next Olympics, wearing a burka, and I’d know there was only the remotest chance of one ever happening.Run Boris, run.MEANWHILE, back on Channel 4’s Meet The Drug Lords: Inside The Real Narcos, Jason “Foxy” Fox was with the Colombian navy this week and desperate for a look inside one of the incredible home-made submarines they’d confiscated from drug-smugglers.“Is it locked?”“Yes.”And there’ll be more Bafta-worthy action from Foxy and his forward-planning department this week, I’m sure.EVER since it discovered that Danny Dyer was the rightful heir to the English throne, Who Do You Think You Are? has been struggling to find a purpose, or indeed a celebrity, who could see the bigger picture.That special someone who would acknowledge history’s great events with more than a few “wows” and shrugs and not think their own career made all of their ancestors’ suffering worthwhile.Finally, last night, they found him.Judge Robert Rinder, who as well as having the best brain at ITV (Luna the Labrador off This Morning has the second best) also turns out to be a natural television journalist, telling the story of his maternal great-grandfather, Israel, and his beloved grandfather, Morris, simply, beautifully and without ever letting the details overwhelm him.The former fled revolutionary Latvia at the turn of the last century.The latter’s entire family was wiped out in Treblinka’s gas chambers.Yet he somehow survived the Buchen-wald, Theresienstadt and Schlieben concentration camps and made it to Britain, which offered him salvation, friendship, justice and, above all, a sense that “life is worth living” that has been passed down through eternally grateful generations.It’s a remarkable story, so if you missed it, try to catch tonight’s repeat (BBC1, 11.25pm).SCENES and characters the viewers are unlikely to forget in a hurry on the final episode of BBC2’s wonderful Travels In Trumpland With Ed Balls.First stop, the President’s Mar-a-Lago compound in Florida, where Ed spent the most uncomfortable night of his life, since Strictly, at a one-year-in-office party for Trump, with Toni Holt Kramer and a group of fans who were called The Trumpettes, but could well have been the provisional wing of The Golden Girls.If you thought they were a bit sinister, though, he was then off squirrel hunting in the forests of Georgia with two hillbillies who might not have been plucking banjos but they certainly had the mad cackling laughs and slightly unsettling line in hospitality.“Are you ready to be a man today, Ed?” asked one, as you began to wonder if he could escape with his dignity intact, let alone blend in with the local gene pool.Then he suddenly reappeared – and this was a masterstroke – wearing a Norwich City scarf.Scrub everything I ever said about Ed Balls.The man’s a diplomatic genius.Sent in by Rob Milner, East Yorkshire. Picture research: Alfie SnellingTHIS Morning, Wednesday:Gok Wan: “Coming up, Ninja nanas, in a minute, John Torode’s in the Lake District at 11.45, and we’ve got the return of the Hawaiian shirt at midday.“First, would you like to live ten years longer?”Ten years? Right now I’m ambivalent abOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: first part time jobs sun writers
story: The number of 16 to 17-year-olds taking part-time jobs has more than halved since 1997, dropping from 42 per cent to 18 per cent. It means young people are missing out on essential skills as they approach adulthood.GRANT ROLLINGS asked five Sun columnists what their first part-time jobs were and the valuable lessons they learned – from being polite to skiving.I ALWAYS had a summer job, usually it meant working full-time hours on my normal Saturday job as holiday cover. This was either in a boutique such as Chelsea Girl or in BHS, where I worked on the sweetie counter.I coped with the boredom by sneakily munching on the best chocolate sweets from the pick-and-mix. I also worked as a waitress in a trendy Glasgow eaterie during the holidays.All of these jobs gave me the most enormous respect for the men and women who toil for long hours, often dealing with unreasonable members of the public for too little pay and not much prospect of promotion.Working in the service industry taught me the power of a disarming smile, and proved that my old granny’s saying that “you get more in life from sugar than vinegar” could not be more true.Grumpy customers demanding refunds and diners moaning that they had been waiting too long for their main course were usually placated with a swift apology and a promise to sort things out.A major restaurant blunder could often be smoothed over with a free coffee or pudding.MY favourite summer job came in 1977. I was a traffic enumerator for Middlesbrough Council. That meant I spent all day counting cars. All the way up one side of Linthorpe Road, all the way back down the other.I had to write down all the number plates. In the end, I got a bit bored and spent the time hanging out at my mate’s T-shirt shop or Fearnley Records and made the numbers up, always remembering to have them end in the local codes of HN or (I think) XG. I hope the council thought it worthwhile.It was better than the glue factory, where I’d been very briefly working on a weighbridge. Foreman pressed a button and this vast door opened and thousands of rotting animal carcasses fell out. I can still smell it now, all these years later. I passed out — soft lad, you see.Or there was working the nightshift pricing cans of food and stuff in Hintons, the local convenience store. Every time I turned up, the manager would say, ‘Here he is, the poor man’s Rod Stewart’.A friend of mine, Mark, had a much better summer job.He was a Club 18-30 holiday rep. He shagged 21 girls in 25 days, which gave me my first story to sell to the national newspapers.MY first holiday job was in the summer of 1985 when I was 16 years old. I had already been turned down from working at Waitrose in Enfield Town on the basis I was “too glamorous”.That just goes to show how far we have come in such a short time. I have never set foot in a Waitrose since that day because I was beyond furious. Anyway, the job I did get was working in a hairdresser’s on Goodge Street in London.My journey involved three changes and about 14 stops every day. The job was meant to be answering the phone, sweeping up and generally helping out, but before the end of the first week I was running the till, the appointment system, cashing up and generally managing the place.The only thing I could not do was cut hair, but that didn’t stop me cutting my friends’ hair — with very mixed results, more bad than good — on the basis I worked in a hairdresser’s so they thought I should. I remember the liberating feeling of earning my own money, it gave me the greatest sense of independence, self-esteem and self-belief.I worked out I was actually good in a work environment, talking to people — for example, talking women into perms they didn’t want — being responsible, handling money and making a difference to my employer.The biggest transition we make in our lives is leaving education to go into the workplace, and summer jobs prepare you for this.I HAD dozens of summer jobs, from working as a scaffolder’s mate with a convicted murderer, who kept a pistol in the glove compartment of his Ford Escort, to donning a white suit and Geiger counter to carry out maintenance on the core of the main reactor at a nuclear power station.I learned a hundred things from each and every job, but it was working as a grocery assistant at my local supermarket that had the most impact.My best friend and I both got jobs there at the same time. He was a star performer at school, a brilliant academic, but he couldn’t take the pace and got fired after a couple of months.It was incredibly hard, repetitive work.The manager was an ex-Army major — very strict on haircuts, discipline and stealing.There was always the prospect of the Tannoy announcement “customer service one hundred”, which was code for a shoplifter having been spotted.All the male floor staff were required to assemble at till number one to tackle the suspect, who would sometimes become violent.I was much happier making the cheese look pretty and eventually became the ruler of the entire soft dairy aisle — a project I’m still working on.I WAS 13 in Brownes Wine bar, Stafford Street, Derby, summer 1987, some years before it burned down in mysterious circumstances (has a bar ever burnt down innocently?). I was chief bottler-up.This involved the soul-sapping exercise of sifting through bins taller than me for all the recyclable bottles from the previous night’s festivities and putting them in their correct crates. This took all morning and you ended up cut to shreds and stinking of Britvic and Schlitz.I was then asked to be the cook — this involved microwaving lasagne for drunk people. I was paid the princely sum of £3 per hour. I realised how crap this was, so one scorching Saturday I nicked the shampoo that came with my dad’s company car and took advantage of the sketchy Eighties attitude to drink-driving and washed all the customers’ cars in the car park for a fiver a pop.I literally cleaned up. It was the greatest Dragons’ Den moment I’ve ever had. I waxed on and off all day, rinsing my dad of his prized BMW product. He arrived to pick me up and I was minted. A 13-year-old with £64 in his pocket. That coveted Swatch would finally be mine.He then told me the dog had been run over, so that’s another memory ruined.Thanks for reminding me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn is unfit to be labour leader
story: His entire political career has been spent in close company with anti- Semites, terrorist sympathisers and extremists.So it shouldn’t be a surprise that he was pictured appearing to pay his respects to Black September, the terror group which murdered 11 Israelis and one German policeman at the Munich Olympics.That’s a group that not only killed in cold blood but tortured and brutalised their victims too.It is genuinely shocking that the Leader of the Opposition is so willing to lie about it. To say that he was “present but not involved” is an insult to voters’ intelligence when photographs show him holding a wreath and gurning for a nearby camera.To allow his press office to say the widows of those murdered in Munich were being “misled” is, even among the many shameful episodes we’ve seen since he became Labour leader three hate-filled years ago, disgraceful.The most vital qualification for power in this country must be integrity. And Jeremy Corbyn has demonstrated this week that he has absolutely none of it.But for all of the shame that he brings upon Labour, it is nothing compared to the spinelessness of the party’s “moderate” MPs whose opposition to Corbyn extends not much further than wishy-washy tweets.“Present but not involved” isn’t an excuse for Corbyn but nor is it for the cowards on Labour’s backbenches.Corbyn cannot be allowed near government. But the rest of the party has lost the public’s faith too.TOMORROW, official figures are likely to suggest that train fares will go up by another 3.5 per cent in January.If you’re a commuter who has put up with delayed and cancelled trains, you’ll be wondering what you’re paying for.After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum found period stains new dress pretty little thing
story: Sacha Brown, 38, said she was livid when she discovered her £8 bargain from Pretty Little Thing was soiled with blood.She quickly washed her hands several times after taking delivery of the white lace bodycon dress on Monday — bought ahead of a holiday to St Lucia with her son next week.Nail technician Sasha, from Surbiton, South West London, told The Sun Online: Im going on holiday next Monday with my nine-year-old son to St Lucia in the Caribbean.I decided to order some new clothes from Pretty Little Things online to take on holiday with me.Among the items was a white lace bodycon dress reduced to £8.The dress arrived this afternoon and I opened it up to take a look at it and make sure it fits before packing it away.But when I looked at the lining I noticed three large blood stains — I was like, What the actual f***.I am livid. I could not believe what I was seeing.She had picked up her clothing from the popular clothes site - which targets women aged 16 to 34.It has gone on to become one of the biggest names in online fashion since its launch six years ago, with its clothes modelled by superstars like Kourtney Kardashian.But South Londoner Sasha was less than impressed with her shopping experience.She added: I am absolutely convinced it is blood stains from a period. As a woman, you know these things when you see them.Someone has obviously ordered the dress and tried it on without wearing underwear or a pad before sending it back.Who would do something like that? I just think its so disgusting.I washed my hands four times after.This is my first bad experience with Pretty Little Thing. The prices are reasonable — I just wanted a few cheap things to take on holiday with me.But now I would seriously reconsider shopping with them ever again.They have exposed me to someone elses blood — I expect compensation. I am very upset.A spokesperson for Pretty Little Thing said: We’re really sorry to hear Sacha has received her item this way. Our customer service team have contacted Sacha and she has been issued a full refund on her order and we’ll be looking further into this.

title: newborn baby schoolgirl 15 found bin parents lancashire home
story: The teenager has revealed to police investigating the death of the babe that she did not know she was pregnant until she went in labour in the bathroom of her family home in Wesham, Lancashire.Lancashire Police are investigating the circumstances of the boys death last Thursday at the house in Garstang Road North.They are trying to find out whether a criminal offence or an offence under the Coroners Act has been committed.The teenager spent two days in hospital after the birth of the child.After that she was interviewed by police.She revealed that after she delivered the baby she placed the childs body in the bin.Her mother and father- he is a former serviceman- were out at the time.The teen was later found by a relative who rang emergency services.A post mortem has been carried out and police are awaiting the outcome of medical tests.

title: girl 6 secretly ordered 250 toys ipad
story: This image of a grinning Caitlin went viral, as the cheeky youngster welcomed home her delivery to the shock of her unsuspecting parents.Beaming, the image shows the youngster standing on the side of the road as boxes are off-loaded outside her house.The massive Amazon order only came to light when the courier turned up at the family home in Utah, leaving the girl’s mum, aunt and cousin stunned.Posting an image of the hilarious moment to Twitter, her cousin Ria wrote: “My badass little cousin ordered $300 worth of toys w/o my aunt &amp uncle knowing. This is a picture of how everyone found out.”As the story unfolded, it emerged that Cailtin’s mum had allowed the child to order a Barbie doll as a birthday present on Amazon.Days later, when the cheeky schoolgirl asked if she could check the status of her order, her mum unwittingly obliged.3 3The following morning, six boxes landed on the family’s doorstep, leaving the surprised parent scratching her head.Ria explained: “Her mom went on her Amazon account and saw three pages of things she had ordered.”While many online applauded the child’s guts and intelligence for actually managing to pull the stunt off, Caitlin was forced to return every single item ordered.She was allowed to keep the birthday Barbie doll, though.As the story of Caitlin’s antics did the rounds on Twitter, others came forward to share their own hilarious experiences of “smart” children and online shopping dramas.Jessy Fine’Too said: “My son did this during Christmas time a few years ago and I called amazon in tears and they let me keep everything and refunded my money.”Ashley V concurred: “When my son did it they offered to extend my prime membership for an additional 3 months for free... He ordered $473 worth of toys.. And a white comforter”While Joy added: “My neighbours 10 year old told Alexa to send him a case of dishwashing soap. We all got some :)”

title: driver 5 point turn motorway tamworth
story: Excruciating footage shows a Mercedes driver heading the wrong way up a busy dual carriageway with a flat tyre - and bringing the traffic to a grinding halt as they attempt the manoeuvre.Fellow road user Stuart Hatton can be heard effing and blinding in a video he took of the debacle on Saturday.As he zooms in on the offending driver he says: “What the f***. We all nearly had a f****** head on collision.As the car turns around in the middle of the slip road, the 48-year-old driver continues: “F****** flat tyre as well, f****** t**t. Get to f***.”The clip was filmed on the A5 in Tamworth as Mr Hatton was travelling north of the town centre.His footage ends with the driver finally making the turn and driving off, to which Stuart says: “F****** idiot, f****** hell.”The irate driver from Tamworth, Staffordshire, uploaded the footage to Facebook where it has since received more than 61,000 views.The service engineer captioned the post: “Just getting off the A5 by Asda. This prat driving up the slip road wrong way.“He was much further up than this and reversed all the way back down. Haha.”Caroline Yates said: “Just as well for him that it is not called a three point turn anymore!”Tj Sinista Cheetham commented: “Wow. Silly b*****ks has a puncture too. How some people passed their test is beyond me.”While Claudia Hodgett added: “How did he not manage the three point turn with that much room.”Speaking today, service engineer Stuart said the driver was an “idiot.”He said: “He reversed mostly the way down before I filmed it.“I couldnt film as I was driving.“It was only when we got near the bottom. I filmed once I had stopped the vehicle.“At first we were going at speed joining the exit road thats when I seen brake lights come on and noticed the car coming the other way.“Travelling 60 mph to join a slip road - you need to start slowing down on there because of the bend.”

title: not getting enough sleep makes men and women appear less approachable and attractive
story: Scientists found it makes men and women appear less approachable and attractive.Those who are sleep deprived typically feel lonelier and try to avoid human contact, just like those with social anxiety.Their vibe can even make people feel withdrawn in their company after 60 seconds.Just cutting kip time by a couple of hours can make a difference after one night.Boffins monitored the brains of 18 people as they watched a video of someone walking towards them.Those who were sleep deprived had less activity in regions that encourage social engagement. And there was more action in areas that fire when someone feels their personal space is  invaded.In another trial, 1,000 people rated videos of others chatting.Those from films who had the least sleep scored worse for desirability and perceived loneliness.The volunteers also felt more isolated after watching a sleep-deprived person talk.Study leader Prof Matthew Walker, of the University of California, said: “We humans are a social species. Yet sleep deprivation can turn us into social lepers.“The less sleep you get, the less you want to socially interact.“In turn, other people perceive you as more socially repulsive, further increasing the grave social-isolation impact of sleep loss. That vicious cycle may be a significant contributing factor to the public health crisis that is loneliness.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brazen uber eats man pictured cycling m5 motorists
story: The snap shows the man, laden with his huge backpack, pedalling close to the central reservation as traffic speeds past him - despite cyclists being banned from using motorways.He was clocked close to junction two at Oldbury, West Midlands, at around 11.30 am.Watch Commander at Oldbury Fire tweeted the image - and urged the company to educate riders so his team arent lifting a HGV off them.He wrote: “How do you recruit staff who are willing to risk their lives @UberEats? This captured just now #M5 j2 #Oldbury.“Please educate your riders so that my team and I from @Oldburyfire aren’t lifting a HGV off them. #UberEats #Uber #MotorwayMadness (Police aware).”Uber said it was investigating and that the safety of customers, couriers and the general public is a top priority.A spokesman said: All couriers are required to adhere to the Highway Code and any report of a courier breaching road laws can result in being removed from the Uber Eats app.It is unclear how the delivery rider ended up on the motorway, which was even more congested due to roadworks.

title: chris grayling urges rail bosses cap pay demands
story: Amid a fierce Tory rebellion over higher ticket prices, the Secretary of State urged unions and train companies to switch to the less generous CPI measure of inflation when negotiating pay deals.They are currently based on the higher Retail Prices Index – as are fares.Insiders said the switch could save £1.4 billion between now and 2024.Mr Grayling said: “It is difficult to justify using a different measure on inflation to the one that is widely used across services like the NHS.”But furious Tory MPs described the pleas as “hopeless”.And former Cabinet Minister Priti Patel became the latest to attack a possible 3.5 per cent rise in ticket prices.Today’s RPI inflation figures – likely to be 3.5 per cent - set the base for January’s upcoming rise.She stormed: “This kind of increase is totally unwarranted right now.”  And Tory campaigner Rob Halfon said the eye-watering increases risked destroying Theresa May’s pledge to care for hard-up Brits.He told The Sun: “The Prime Minister spoke about helping the ‘just about managing’.“If this is to be more than words we should sure we don’t let these fares rise in the way it looks like they are going to. We’re talking about raising fares, fuel duty, other taxes … this is not what the Conservative party should be about.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. She isn’t shocked or surprised by his behaviour and dealt with it all with a lot of grace.” Meghan has not spoken to Thomas since he staged a series of paparazzi photos.He did not go to her wedding in May after suffering a heart attack.Meghan’s sister Samantha, 53, has also urged her to contact their dad, who lives in Mexico.And she described Meghan and Harry’s handling of the crisis as “feeble, inept and negligent”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gay couple defend ben stokes affray
story: Prosecutors had claimed the cricket ace acted in an anti-gay manner towards Kai Barry and William O’Connor by flicking cigarette butts at them and mocking their walks.But after the 27-year-old star was cleared of affray yesterday and recalled to the England Test squad, they rubbished the accusations.And they maintained married Stokes only stepped in to save them from being attacked by two “bullies”.Hairdresser Kai, 27, said: “We were attacked only because we were gay. Ben was heroic — thank you Ben!“We are convinced we would have been beaten up if it wasn’t for Ben. He stood up for us.“I got bottled and Ben jumped in to defend me. The prosecution said he was homophobic, but we never saw any of that.“If he didn’t like me, or didn’t worry about me or was taunting me, then he wouldn’t have stuck up for me in the first place.“We’re delighted that he’s been cleared. He risked his career for us.“We didn’t want Ben’s career ruined for helping two people who were being attacked.“Just a week before the case the Crown Prosecution Service said they didn’t want us there. I think police and the CPS ignored that it happened to us because we’re gay.”They appeared on Good Morning Britain and sent a message to Stokes after saying he had taken a risk when coming to their aid.Kai said: Id just like to say thank you for what you did. Im so sorry it went down like that, I shouldnt have lasted that long  in the first place.And William added: Thank you as well, it was brilliant what youve done, stuck up for two gay men - you dont really get people out there like that so you definitely did a very good job.Both Kai and 21-year-old student beautician William gave full ­statements to officers after video footage of the Bristol punch-up was handed to The Sun last year.But they were told prosecutors did not want them to give ­evidence, so their account of how they believe Stokes stepped in to ­rescue them was never heard by the jury.They described exactly how the star, cleared at Bristol crown court, selflessly leapt to their rescue.They said he waded in with his fists during the brawl last September only after they were branded “batty boys” and then attacked with the glass bottle.Kai and William said they were out drinking in the city’s popular Clifton Triangle when they got chatting to Stokes outside a nightclub called Mbargo.The pair told how they laughed and joked with the ace about his £695 white Buscemi hi-top trainers while smoking a ­cigarette at 2am.William said: “I was chatting to Ben, but I didn’t know it was him at the time. I laughed at his shoes and he laughed too.”But he and Kai, who describe themselves as openly gay and flamboyant, said they were then targeted with homophobic taunts as they walked away.Kai said: “The other two defendants Ryan Ali and Ryan Hale walked behind us.“We then heard a ‘batty boy’ comment. I turned around and confronted them and was hit in the back with a bottle.“Ben Stokes came across the road to stop it — you can clearly see it on the video.”All-rounder Stokes, 27, had faced jail after knocking out two men during a street brawl following a booze- fuelled night out with team-mate Alex Hales, 29, in Bristol last September.But after a six-day trial, jurors took just 2½ hours to clear him of the charge.In a statement read outside Bristol crown court, his solicitor Paul Lunt said The Sun’s footage of the street fight showed “jurors exactly what happened”.He added: “Today’s verdict represents the end of an 11-month ordeal for Ben during which time he has had to maintain his silence.“The jury’s decision fairly reflects the truth of what happened that night.“Ben had been out with team-mates celebrating an England win. He was minding his own business when he came across two men who were subject to what Ben identified as serious homophobic abuse.“It was only when others came under threat that Ben became physically engaged.“The steps that he took were solely aimed at ensuring the safety of himself and the others present.“In addition to the ext­reme stress placed on Ben and his family by the trial, his intervention that night has already cost Ben the England vice-captaincy, his place on an Ashes tour and his place on a number of other England matches.“The past 11 months have served to highlight just how highly he values his posit­i­on as an England representative. Now the trial is over, he’s keen to get back to cricket being his sole focus.”As the jury delivered its verdict Stokes closed his eyes, rocked forward and pressed his head against the dock’s glass screen.The court heard how the 6ft 2in star stepped in to defend gay pals Kai Barry and William O’Connor outside a Bristol club.He hit two other men but said it was self defence.Stokes was yesterday re­called to the England squad and could regain his place in the team for Saturday’s third Test at Trent Bridge.Avon and Somerset Police said in a statement they had carried out “a thorough independent inv­estigation” into the events.They added: “The jury has concluded the actions of the defendants did not amount to affray and we respect this decision.”The film shows former shopping mall security guard Ali, 28, hitting Kai on the back with a ­bottle before he was laid out by Stokes. The cricketer also KO’d 27-year-old Afghanistan veteran Hale.Both Hale and Ali were also cleared of affray by the court.William said he recalled the moment Ali hit Kai with a bottle in the street and is still shocked.He said: “It was aggressive. It was out of nowhere. We aren’t boys going out looking for trouble. Ben stood up for us and — after a bit of wrestling — knocked them both out.“We got out of there because we could have got hurt.”Kai added: “I thank God every day for Ben being there. God only knows what could have happened if he wasn’t.”Stokes, who left court yesterday hand-in-hand with wife Clare, 28 — mum to their two children — told the trial he was sticking up for Kai and William. But while his defence is backed up by the pair, they were not asked to give evidence in court.William went on: “He went out of his way to stick up for two gay boys he didn’t know rather than leave us at the mercy of two people starting on us.“He stood his ground for us. He stood up for two gay boys and not many people would do that.“I feel really bad it got this far. If I ever did meet Ben again I would thank him for doing what he did — and apologise for laughing at his trainers.”The pair rubbished claims from nightclub bouncer Andrew Cunningham that Stokes had been “spiteful” and “bullied” Kai and William during their exchange outside the club. They said footage of Stokes flicking them a cigarette was “harmless banter”.William said: “From what we experienced, Ben Stokes is not the nasty or homophobic person he was painted as in court. He stood up for two gay boys.“We were just having banter outside the club. Ben was messing around making gestures, but I have banter with my friends like that.“The police said he was making hand gestures at me, but I get that a lot and I’m still friends with these sorts of people.“My friends do it as well, it’s taking the p***, but it’s not like a bad p***, we clearly didn’t take offence to it.“If it was that bad and he didn’t really like us that much, then he wouldn’t have stuck up for us in the first place.”The six-day trial had also been told that Stokes was “aggressive” and had “lost control” before hitting Hale.William said: “On the video it looks aggressive. But he only did it because of the homophobic abuse — and because Kai had been hit with a bottle.“Ben is a hero for doing what he did. If he wasn’t there, we’d be in hospital.”  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chancellor hopes negotiated brexit deal
story: Addressing voters, the German Chancellor said an “unregulated” or ‘No Deal’ Brexit was in no one’s interests.“Hopefully it will not come to an unregulated Brexit, but rather to a reasonable, negotiated agreement,” she said.But she said that if Britain ever wanted to “benefit” from the EU in the future it had to be prepared to “commit to re-accepting EU rules”.Tory insiders claim Theresa May talked Ms Merkel through her soft Brexit Chequers plan before she briefed her Cabinet – claims denied by No.10.Yesterday’s comments came as Tory Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt demanded the European Commission “change its approach” and open the door to a Brexit agreement.Starting a three-day tour of Europe in Helsinki, Finland the Tory big hitter said the risks of a ‘No Deal’ were “increasing”.And he said the EU faced a strategic choice to move the negotiations forward and strike an agreement that “works in our mutual interests”.He said: “My simple message is that we need to take that opportunity.”The Tory leadership contender risked upsetting arch Eurosceptics on the backbenches by saying “no one wants” a ‘No Deal’.But the salvo echoes a similar blast last month when Mr Hunt warned the EU it was on the verge of sleepwalking into a ‘No Deal’ by accident.Commission chiefs say there are still big obstacles to meeting an October deadline for agreeing a framework agreement for the future trading arrangements between the UK and EU.Jeremy Hunt is also taking in Latvia, Denmark and the Netherlands on his trip.GOT a story? title: surge brits in work as eu nationals
story: Official figures yesterday revealed another surge in employment and unemployment at a 43-year low despite Brexit fears.The number of people in work rose by 42,000 in the three months to June to 32.39 million – 313,000 higher than last summer.And the Office for National Statistics showed the ‘net’ rise was almost exclusively accounted for by UK nationals getting a job.The number of UK nationals in work has jumped by 332,000 since June 2017 to almost 28.8 million.Only the number of Romanians and Bulgarians in work has gone up in the past year, by 54,000 to a whopping 391,000.There are also an extra 50,000 Indians with a job than a year ago.Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey said that with the unemployment rate at a 43-year low of 4 per cent “the vibrant jobs market is benefiting people across the board”.“More families across society are benefiting from the security of a job, with wages also on the increase,” she said.But business groups warned a ‘Brexodus’ of EU workers was already “hampering firms’ ability to compete”.CBI employment chief Matthew Percival said: “The Government needs to guarantee that EU workers can continue to work even in a ‘No Deal’ scenario.”Experts separately warned pay growth – at 2.4 per cent – was “anaemic” despite hopes firms will have to loosen the purse strings if EU staff head home.But Migration Watch chairman Lord Green countered: “The rise in UK born workers is most welcome. If immigration can be successfully controlled and reduced, this increase is likely to continue.”The official figures separately revealed the number of zero-hours contracts in use has fallen by 104,000 over the past year to 780,000.It marks the first substantial fall recorded by the ONS since it began tracking the figures in 2000.TUC general secretary Frances o’Grady said: “Bosses are finally getting the message that zero-hours contracts are legalised exploitation.”Vote for Brexit and you’d start a recession the likes of which you couldn’t imagine, they said. Well, two years later, Britain’s unemployment figures are at their lowest in more than 40 years.Not exactly plague and pestilence.But as Remoaners rev up their second referendum campaign, it’s worth remembering that it’s exactly the same people that ran Project Fear in the run-up to the 2016 vote.And each of their predictions has turned out to be absolute rubbish.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: married vicar had fling with curate
story: The Rev Rupert Kalus — who converted from Catholicism as he couldn’t face a vow of celibacy — was forced to quit when his affair with the Rev Ali Miller was discovered.Mrs Miller, wed to a vicar in a nearby parish, has also quit. The Bishop of Durham broke the news to shocked parishioners during a service last weekend at All Saints Church in Lanchester, County Durham.One worshipper said: “It came completely out of the blue. No one had a clue. It’s so sad because they both have partners and children.”Another said: “Some people are calling him Randy Rupe.“When you consider the church’s teaching it is out of order.” Mr Kalus, a dad of three, had been a vicar in Lanchester and Burnhope for the past 12 years.The former Catholic switched to the Church of England as he felt unable to stick to his celibacy vow.On arriving in the parish in 2006 Mr Kalus, 56, said: “I thought I had a vocation to the priesthood but I hadn’t a vocation to celibacy because I wanted to get married.”The ex-teacher grew close to Mrs Miller, 42, when she was a trainee at the two parish churches of All Saints and St John’s. She was ordained in 2015.Mr Kalus was to start a new role in Kilburn, North London, this year.GOT a story? title: katie stubblefield youngest face transplant recipient
story: Katie Stubblefield underwent a pioneering 31 hour operation in Cleveland, Ohio, on May 4, 2017  – over two years after she aimed the gun at her chin and pulled the trigger.The brave young woman, who now has the face of a mother who died of a drug overdose, told National Geographic: “I get a second chance at life now.”Katie, from Oxford, Mississippi, tried to take her own life on March 25, 2014, after her boyfriend dumped her.Her brother Robert, whose hunting rifle the then-schoolgirl had used, told Nat Geo that his sister’s “face was gone” when he found her lying on the bathroom floor.She was rushed to a hospital in Memphis, Tennessee, where doctors stabilised her jaw and cheekbones and sewed her eyelids shut to enable her damaged corneas to heal.Katie’s skull was also opened as medics stopped the bleeding on her brain.However, when her skin grafts kept failing she was transferred to Cleveland Clinic – a world leader in face transplants.Doctors in Ohio repaired the youngster’s bone structure, including her nose, nasal passage and jaw.At the end of 2015, she was finally declared stable and placed on the transplant list in March the following year.She was given hours of therapy to help her prepare for the aftermath of the operation and the considerable psychological impact having another persons face can cause.Then on May 4 last year, Katie became only the eighth person in the US to undergo face transplant surgery.A team of 15 specialist doctors gave her new skin, bone, blood vessels and nerves.The cutting-edge Cleveland hospital even 3D printed a new jaw for Katie using a scan of her older sisters.She was discharged on August 1, 2017 and continues to take a variety of immunosuppressant drugs to ensure her body does not reject her new face.The 22-year-old is also re-learning how to walk and speak while also continuing to undergo therapy.Katie, raised by her Christian minister father and teacher mother, hopes to complete her studies and become a counsellor helping other survivors of suicide.

title: rid harry and meghan turbulent
story: Most of the time, they make the Windsors seem a happy and (almost) normal bunch — no small feat.So why oh why is the Palace spin machine making such a spectacular mess with the Markles?Anybody with half a brain could tell, from the moment Prince Harry and Meghan started dating, that her family could turn into a royal pain in the neck.You’ve got a vengeful and jealous half-sister Samantha, who despises Meghan and has been briefing against her for more than a year.She is now telling hacks that she knows Harry and Meghan’s marriage won’t last, which is charming.Then you’ve got Thomas Markle, the dad, an eccentric character who is furious at being “locked out” of his daughter’s life.Barely a day goes by without Mr Markle hurling another negative headline across the Atlantic in the direction of his new son-in-law.Mr Markle insists that, contrary to official briefings, the rift between him and his daughter continues. He says he was told that he couldn’t speak at the wedding and that Harry berated him on the phone for mishandling the Press while he was recovering from a heart attack.The official royal response to these outbursts has been, effectively, to shove their fingers in their ears and shout la-la-la (or lah-lah-lah).The snobby courtiers and hangers-on dismiss Markle père as fame-hungry.That’s not altogether wrong — he is clearly desperate, as he proved by posing for snaps with the paparazzi in the run-up to the wedding.But it’s not good enough to wish he’d just go away.Meghan is now one of the most photographed and sought-after women in the world. Her very well-paid PR flunkies should have seen these familial landmines a mile off and defused them.But they have failed.Thomas Markle is a difficult and proud man, no doubt. But that is why he should have been treated with care, not frozen out.Why did Team Windsor not find him a role and approach him long before the wedding to make sure he didn’t feel excluded.It’s hard not to feel for him.His ex, Meghan’s mother Doria, was hailed as one of the stars of the wedding.Because she’s a black woman, she invited lots of gushing commentary about the monarchy becoming more diverse and modern.Amen to that. But poor old podgy Thomas, an awkward-looking white bloke, has been shunned from his daughter’s nuptials. You can’t blame him for speaking out.The royal courtiers enjoy the adulation the monarchy receives because Prince Harry has been “brave” enough to marry a woman with a complicated background.But the Palace spin machine freaks out when it comes to confronting the reality of Meghan’s parentage.Perhaps they just find it too vulgar.Harry’s PR man is Jason Knauf, an American specialist in “crisis management” having worked for Royal Bank of Scotland. He excels at sending angry letters to journalists he feels have gone too far snooping into Harry and Meghan’s private lives.But he doesn’t seem to have a clue as to how to handle his clients’ grumpy relatives.As a result, the monarchy is facing arguably its worst crisis since the death of Princess Diana.We are often told how brilliant the Royal Family’s PR is. Part of the new royal spin, in fact, is about how great the royals now are at spin. They have “rebranded” the monarchy for the 21st century, and so on.Look at the blizzard of positive guff accompanying Prince William, Kate, and Harry’s campaign for mental illness last year.They were, it was said, making the younger Windsors seem more touchy-feely.At the moment, however, they don’t seem sensitive enough to speak to Meghan’s suffering in-laws.That’s not what you’d call a good look.The truth is, royal press officers have long got too much credit.The British admire the Queen because she is admirable.Overall, we prefer monarchy to any other system of government. That’s just common sense. It’s nothing to do with any ingenious branding and media strategy.The public also feels that the younger royals deserve a chance.At a time when our country is consumed by Brexit and political arguments, the wedding of Harry and Meghan came as a blessed relief — something we could all celebrate.The couple both came from broken homes, and nobody cared so long as they were happy. That’s all great.   But it’s obvious that Meghan has, as one royal expert put it, “background baggage that needs unpacking”.Insiders now say the treatment of the Markle family has been a “shambles”.This is before we consider the potential PR bombshells that could erupt if and when Meghan’s ex-husband, Trevor Engelson, decides to grant some interviews.The British don’t want to see the monarchy turned into a reality TV soap, as the Markles and Windsors wage a media war with each other.It’s trashy and embarrassing.But unless the Palace can tackle Meghan’s disgruntled kin, that’s exactly what is happening.Maybe we need a changing of the royal PR guard — before it’s too late.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
